David,

Thanks for answering so quickly! 

Actually that's exactly what I d=
id. At first, I had multiple versions
of the same fixture lying around my T=
estCases. As I found myself
writing more identical fixtures, I began to thi=
nk about finding a
central place for these (in order to keep my code DRY an=
d avoid a
maintenance nightmare further down the road). 

Using inheritance=
 and placing the common fixtures in a super class
seemed to be the right wa=
y to go. In fact, it worked quite well as
long as my classes only implement=
ed one interface. However, as soon as
I stumbled upon a class implementing =
two of these interfaces, I was
faced with a choice of which super TestCase =
to extend=85

I realize that maybe this isn't the right way to go but I'd l=
ike to be
sure before I throw it all away and try another path=85

I'll pos=
t the results of my "quest" if I ever find an interesting
solution.

Yours,=


Dimitri

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <saff@m...> wrote:
> D,=

> 
> It's an interesting problem.  Have you tried going at it
incrementall=
y?  
> Go ahead and write the unit tests for two or three of your classes, =

> cutting and pasting if necessary.  Then go back and see what you
have to=
 
> do to remove the duplication.  I often find this to be an effective way=
 
> to make an abstract question concrete.
> 
> If, in the midst of doing t=
his exercise, you find yourself with a
small, 
> focused example of a place=
 where you would be tempted to use multiple 
> inheritance, please post it.=
  I'm willing to bet, with even odds, that 
> you'll quickly find other way=
s of gracefully doing what you need.  Good 
> luck,
> 
>     David Saff
> 
=
> Java Questions wrote:
> 
> > Hi everyone,
> >
> > I'm faced with a "desig=
n problem" and I was hoping that some
> > experienced developer could help =
me figure out how to sort it out.
> >
> > I use a lot of small interfaces i=
n my application, each of which has a
> > very precise purpose. Most of my =
"concrete" classes implement more
> > than one of these interfaces.
> >
> >=
 Now, I was hoping to find a way to refactor my tests so that each
> > inte=
rface has its own abstract TestCase. Then, if multiple inheritance
> > was =
allowed in Java, I could simply implement each classes concrete
> > classe'=
s TestCase by inheriting from all the appropriate "interface
> > TestCases"=
.
> >
> > This would allow me to inherit all the general purpose fixtures a=
nd
> > simply add some new fixtures targeted for the concrete classe's
> > =
specific behavior. In a way, I simply want to enforce the "Liskov
> > Subst=
itution Principle" as simply as possible...
> >
> > I know multiple inherit=
ance isn't allowed in Java and should be
> > avoided anyway but I'd like to=
 find a simple way to keep the general
> > idea of "interface specific supe=
r TestCases" and apply it to classes
> > implementing several of these inte=
rfaces.
> >
> > Is the general idea a good one ? If it is, what is  the bes=
t way to 
> > achieve it ?
> >
> > Thanks in advance,
> >
> > D.
> >
> >
> =
>
> >
> >
